item.title: Kitaab launches its inaugural crowdfunding campaign
item.description: Source: Kitaab website. Kitaab, meaning “book” in many Asian languages, is entering a new stage: crowdfunding on Indiegogo. Established in 2005, this literary initiative aims to empower Asian writers and connect them with a global audience. Founder and renowned author Zafar Anjum explains that Kitaab has successfully addressed a significant gap in the online Asian literary scene by creating a comprehensive, link-based repository of information focused on Asian writers and their work.

item.title: ImageCrowd has identified a market opportunity for an Asian stock photography marketplace
item.description: ImageCrowd, a new multilingual platform, wants to make it easier to find Asian photography. They connect international buyers with Asian photographers in their native languages. Buyers can make specific image requests, and ImageCrowd will crowdsource photographers to find the perfect match. Both professional and amateur photographers can submit photos. Any photos not purchased are added to a stock photography database. “These days, visual campaigns need to be highly targeted,” says Gijs Waverijn, CEO of ImageCrowd.

item.title: Exploration of business systems in Asia
item.description: Source: OUP. “The Oxford Handbook of Asian Business Systems”, edited by Michael Witt and Gordon Redding, is the first publication to examine business systems from India to Japan. Oxford University Press, the book’s publisher, states that existing research on “varieties of capitalism” (VOC) and “comparative business systems” heavily emphasizes Europe, Japan, and Anglo-Saxon countries. This book is the first to offer a thorough analysis of the institutional frameworks of most Asian countries and assess the applicability of current theories within the Asian context.
